docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee began showing a new commercial, ''Priority MD,'' dealing with prescription drugs in nine states yesterday, taking on the issue that has grabbed center stage in the presidential campaign. The Democratic National Committee plans to answer it, starting today, in the same nine states -- Arkansas, Delaware, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin. PRODUCER -- Cold Harbor Films ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with a shot of prescription drug bottles. Then Mr. Bush speaking in front of an American flag, meeting with elderly people, shaking hands at an airport rally and speaking from a podium. Vice President Al Gore is shown, looking embarrassed, on television. Then, reinforcing the words of the announcer, graphics declare: ''Interfere with doctors,'' ''The Gore Prescription Plan: Bureaucrats Decide,'' and ''The Bush Rx Plan: Seniors Choose.''
docs.abstract: Article describes new Republican National Committee political advertisement on health maintenance organizations and prescription drugs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore today escalated his attacks against the pharmaceutical industry, criticizing the makers of two prescription drugs by name, calling for greater competition and promoting his plan for a Medicare drug benefit. The drug industry has long been one of Mr. Gore's corporate bogeymen, along with oil, tobacco and insurance. But in today's speech to a forum of elderly people at Florida State University, Mr. Gore expanded his criticism, saying he would veto any legislation extending monopoly patents for prescription drugs. ''You elect me president and I'll veto every one of those bills,'' he said.

headline.main: Gore, in Attack on Drug Industry, Focuses on 2 Medicines

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore escalates his attacks on pharmaceutical industry, criticizing makers of two prescription drugs by name, calling for greater competition and promoting his plan for a Medicare drug benefit; singles out Claritin, antihistamine made by Schering-Plough Corp, and arthritis drug Lodine, made by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gary Taylor was ready to be a free agent. Just as Internet job-search sites and articles in new-economy magazines encourage people to do, Mr. Taylor had decided to quit his job. In this high-desert city of low unemployment and fast growth, Mr. Taylor, a glass installer, thought he could find something much better. Within six weeks of casting about, Mr. Taylor had an offer from a utility company to work on one of its growing number of temporary projects. And local technology companies had dozens of open jobs. But there seemed to be a problem with every prospect. Either it did not pay enough to support his wife and three children, he said, or it lacked the health-care benefits to cover them.

headline.main: Lingering Job Worries Amid a Sea of Plenty; Trying to Cope With Changing Technology

docs.abstract: Boise, Idaho, where jobless rate is around 3.5 percent, reflects realities of new economy in which job prospects are better than ever, but anxiety lingers among workers; a glass installer, Gary Taylor, relates unsuccessful attempt to change his line of work at age 41, while Marcia Craig, who changed jobs when Ore-Ida Foods moved away, finds 'times generally very scary'; photos; graphs; Ore-Ida itself, identified with Idaho, was moved to Pittsburgh by its owner, Heinz; few workers fret over finding jobs in tenth year of boom, but many worry about keeping up with technology to take advantage of new-economy companies; constant turnover is exciting for young, well-educated workers, but uncertainties explain why wage pressure remain modest despite boom (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a cochlear implant user, I found the news that cochlear implants had to be proven ''cost effective'' to insurance companies a sad commentary on health care in our country (''Aid for Deaf as Possible Cost-Saver, Too,'' Aug. 22). Hearing loss is the most misunderstood and invisible of disabilities. It affects virtually every aspect of daily living, not just education or work productivity. Cochlear implants are modern-day miracles, allowing the deaf to hear and speak.
docs.abstract: Arlene Romonoff letter on Aug 22 article on cochlear implants

docs.lead_paragraph: John McCain's unfortunate return bout with melanoma should serve as a wake-up call for the millions of Americans -- especially young Americans -- who still worship the sun, skimp on sunscreen and bare their skin to UV radiation to just within the limits of decency. It should also remind everyone of the importance of self-vigilance. Since no one knows your skin and its many markings better than you, you have primary responsibility for checking often for any changes that could herald skin cancer.

headline.main: Yet Another Reminder: Forget the Suntan

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on preventing and detecting melanoma, serious form of skin cancer; photo (M)
